Award.AwardTitle: Exchange Between the Surfzone and Inner Shelf: The Contribution of Transient Rip Currents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rip currents - narrow jets of strong, offshore-directed flow - are a dangerous beach hazard. They account for the majority of the U.S. life guard rescue effort and potentially play a role in many coastal processes by exchanging material such as sediments, pollutants, and intertidal invertebrates across nearshore ocean systems. Because of their episodic nature, transient rip currents are particularly challenging to observe and our understanding of the processes that drive, sustain, and determine their offshore extent is limited. In this project, the fellow aims to quantify transient rip current exchange across nearshore systems. Results may provide valuable information for the safety of recreational beach goers and improve understanding on the transport of materials across and health of our coastal ecosystems. To broaden participation in marine science, the fellow will mentor a summer undergraduate intern on the use of numerical ocean models. The fellow will also work with a local high school to develop and deliver a marine science curriculum culminating with a career-oriented workshop, the Surf Science Teen Conference.

The transition between the surfzone and the inner continental shelf involves a transition across dynamical regions. While wave breaking dominates the forcing of circulation within the surfzone, the inner shelf is subject to a combination of forces including wave shoaling, buoyancy, and the earth?s rotation. On alongshore-uniform beaches, transient rip currents are potentially the dominant mechanism driving the exchange of material across these regions. In this project, using a wave-resolving Boussinesq model, the fellow aims to develop a better understanding of transient rip current driven exchange. To accomplish this aim, the fellow will conduct a series of simulations over a wide parameter space including both normally and obliquely incident wave conditions and multiple beach slopes. Nearshore vortices will be tracked to analyze their dynamics and quantify the strength as well as offshore extent of transient rip currents. Predictive relationships will be determined between rip current characteristics, their bulk exchange, and the array of incident wave and beach conditions. These characteristics can then be compared to other coastal exchange processes such as wind, Stokes? drift, and internal wave-driven transports. Transient rip current exchange occurs over small scales generally unresolved by coastal circulation models. This work will also contribute towards the parameterization of transient rip current behavior in such models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On the continental shelf, ocean circulation is forced by the combined effect of wind, surface wave, and tidal processes. Coastal circulation drives material exchange and is thus important to many interdisciplinary problems of societal concern such as the transport and dispersal of nearshore larval species and pollutants, the delivery of nutrients, as well as search and rescue operations. Both idealized and realistic numerical models are often used to predict coastal circulation and aid in our understanding of the processes at play. However, the coastal ocean has both a wide range of space-time scales and a transition across dynamical regions. While wave breaking dominates the circulation within the surfzone, just offshore wave shoaling, buoyancy, and the earth’s rotation are all important. This creates computational difficulties in accurately simulating the coastal ocean and necessitates the coupling of numerical models, parameterization of unresolved processes, and downscaling of regional circulation models.

In this project, I conducted numerical modeling studies that quantified the effect of typically unresolved processes in the coastal ocean, such as transient rip currents and internal tides. Transient rip currents are episodic, narrow jets of strong offshore-directed flow, driven by the breaking of individual waves on alongshore-uniform beaches. Transient rip currents were generated with 250 unique simulations of a wave-resolving numerical model and empirical relations were determined to show how rip current strength and offshore extent were related to offshore wave conditions. Internal tides are driven by the interaction of tidal flow over coastal bathymetry. I utilized a realistic numerical ocean model to simulate the effect dissipating internal tides on coastal stratification.

Results from this project are broadly split into two areas of focus for coastal modeling, idealized wave-averaged models and realistic regional models. First, I demonstrate the wave-making capability of a wave-resolving model to reproduce the characteristics of field-based wave measurements (see figure 1). I also show transient rip current exchange to be self-similar and that their statistics can be represented as a function of the background wave field. This is an important first step towards parameterization of this process within wave-averaged models. Second, I show that the downscaling of regional processes is important to reproducing the statistics of coastal temperature and circulation in realistic coastal models. The addition of tides requires extra consideration, as domain size and grid resolution affect the generated internal tide, which modifies mean coastal stratification. These results are documented in multiple conference presentations and scientific journal publications.

As part of the broader impacts of this research, I have introduced the study of coastal physical oceanography to many school-group, educator-training, commercial industry, and public visitors through tours of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography research pier. I have also advised and mentored four undergraduate interns in 3 to 6 month research experiences. Two of these have resulted in publication co-authorship for the undergraduate participants. Additionally, a number of ongoing collaborative efforts are the direct result of this research. The parameterization of transient rip current behavior in regional models has benefitted from the large database of wave-resolved model simulations and investigators within the Office of Naval Research Inner Shelf Initiative have utilized many of the realistic regional modeling products produced.
